BENTONITECERIUMMODIFIEDLDHCOMPOSITECATALYSTFORCATALYTICOZONATIONHIGHCONCENTRATIONINDIGOCARMINEDYESOLUTION CHEN D 1 Introduction 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.3 Catalytic ozonation performance 2.4 Stability test 2.5 Characterizations 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials characterizations 3.2 Catalytic ozonation performance 3.3 Mechanism study 3.4 Comparative study 3.5 Stability test 4 Conclusion CRediT authorship contribution statement References TORRESBLANCAS 2015 T CHENX2024X119560 CHENX2024X119560XD 2026-01-31T00:00:00.000Z 2026-01-31T00:00:00.000Z http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ © 2024 Published by Elsevier B.V. 2024-02-21T09:28:40.904Z http://vtw.elsevier.com/data/voc/AddOnTypes/50.7/nlp S0926860X24000048 Post the execution of ten reaction cycles, the catalyst was segregated for further scrutiny. From the SEM imagery ( Fig. 18 ), it was inferred that the catalyst, devoid of the bentonite support, underwent substantial structural modifications and exhibited signs of corrosion. Conversely, the catalysts supported by bentonite showcased commendable structural preservation. Concurrently, the XRD spectra indicated the absence of certain characteristic peaks in the catalyst lacking bentonite safeguard. These observations collectively suggest that the incorporation of bentonite significantly contributes to the enhancement of the catalyst's corrosion resistance and stability. . Yip Supervision Writing – review & editing b Frank Leung-Yuk Lam a ⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, HKSAR, China Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, HKSAR China Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, HKSAR, China b Department of Chemical and Process Engineering, University of Canterbury, New Zealand Department of Chemical and Process Engineering, University of Canterbury New Zealand Department of Chemical and Process Engineering, University of Canterbury ⁎ Corresponding aouthor. This research tackles the pressing issue of high-concentration indigo carmine (IC) dye degradation, where concentrations reach as high as 6000 mg/L. We synthesized a novel catalyst comprising a bentonite-supported cerium-modified magnesium-aluminum layer double hydroxide (Mg-Al-Ce LDH) composite. Our investigation focused on the catalytic prowess of two versions of this catalyst in decolorizing and degrading the IC dye. Remarkably, these catalysts swiftly decolorized the dye solution within 20 min and achieved an impressive 95% Total Organic Carbon (TOC) removal in 60 min, significantly outperforming the 50% TOC reduction by ozonation without a catalyst. Bentonite's role as a support material was crucial, bolstering the catalysts' stability in demanding conditions. This study heralds a breakthrough in high-concentration dye waste treatment, marking a significant stride toward eco-friendly wastewater management practices. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Catalytic ozonation Layer double hydroxide Indigo carmine dye Bentonite Cerium-modified layer double hydroxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Intense color is one of the main characteristics of colored effluents generated from different industries, such as textiles, laundry, printing, food, cosmetics, and leather [1,2]. It has been reported that the dying process in the textile, paper, and leather industry usually uses only 85% of the dye input, while the remaining 15% must be discharged to the environment as effluents [3]. Even at low concentrations, these effluents are highly visible and, more importantly, affect photochemical activities, including light absorption, toxicity, water chemistry, and algal blooms, in aquatic systems [4]. In particular, Indigo Carmine (IC), C16H8N2Na2O8S2, one of the most commonly used natural dyes extracted from Indigofera tinctoria, has been recognized as a key pollutant contributor in textile industries, e.g., denim pants dyeing [5]. Directly discharging the IC dye effluent is harmful to human health and the ecosystem. Furthermore, direct contact with IC dye will cause permanent damage to the cornea and conjunctiva. Hence, there is a strong need to develop an effective treatment for IC dye to eliminate environmental concerns [6]. In conventional dye manufacturing effluents, the wastewater streams from the dyeing processes are commingled with effluents from ancillary operations, leading to a dilution of the dye concentration prior to discharge. Typically, this results in dye concentrations within the range of 100 to 500 mg/L. Contrastingly, effluents originating exclusively from the dyeing phase of production exhibit markedly higher concentrations, often between 5000 and 8000 mg/L. For enterprises seeking to implement water reuse strategies, devising a robust treatment protocol for this high-concentration dye wastewater is an imperative challenge that must be addressed [7,8]. Serval physical and chemical processes have been applied to solve this problem, such as membrane filtration, adsorption, coagulation, flocculation, and chemical oxidation [9,10]. Advanced Oxidation Processes (AOPs) constitute a set of carefully designed chemical treatment strategies capable of effectively removing organic and inorganic components from wastewater. In recent years, there have been relevant studies on the use of iron or other metallic and non-metallic catalysts for the degradation of common organic pollutant wastewater. However, these often come with the drawbacks of being expensive and not suitable for large-scale applications in factories [11]. Among all, chemical oxidation processes appear promising due to their high efficiency and low energy consumption. Benefiting from the high redox potential of ozone (E0 =2.07 V), the ozonation process is one of the most effective remediation processes used for this purpose [12]. Ozone has excellent selectivity when reacting with aromatic and unsaturated moieties. However, due to the limitation of the operation condition, the ozonation process does not show the expected effect while treating specific types of dyestuffs and chemical auxiliaries present in textile effluents. In order to remove these kinds of compounds, advanced ozonation and catalytic ozonation processes have been developed [13]. To further enhance the performance of the ozonation process, combinative methods have been investigated, such as ozone combined with UV, hydrogen peroxide, metallic ions, different types of catalysts, and even ultrasound [14]. Unlike other combinative methods, heterogeneous catalytic ozonation does not need extra energy and chemical input. It is based on increasing the ozone decomposition rate in aquatic systems, enhancing the generation of hydroxyl radicals [15]. Layer double hydroxides (LDH) show unique advantages among the heterogeneous catalysts [16]. LDH, as a selective adsorbent for anionic pollutants from the aquatic system, can be fixed well with the attached IC dye molecules. The hydroxyl radicals released from the ozone can easily react with IC dye molecules, increasing the effectiveness of ozonation [17,18]. It has been reported that cerium has exceptionally highly redox properties and shows significant catalytic potential for the degradation of organic matter pollutants [19]. Thus, cerium was doped onto the Mg-Al LDH (Mg-Al-Ce LDH) to enhance the efficiency of the catalytic ozonation. However, corrosion of catalysts is a problem that has to be faced, particularly in effluent with a high concentration of pollutants and ozone. Owing to the corrosion of catalysts, the catalytic performance of the LDH will decrease over time [20]. Bentonite, a fine clay material mined from the earth, is widely used to support catalysts with weak mechanical strength. It has been reported that bentonite has high stability under extreme conditions [21]. The combinative LDH and bentonite catalysts were focused on in the present work. The present work focuses on the catalytic ozonation performance of remediation of extremely high-concentration IC dye effluent (6000 mg/L) to trial the stability of catalysts under extreme conditions. Four different materials were assessed: Mg-Al LDH, Mg-Al-Ce LDH, a composite of bentonite and Mg-Al LDH (B/Mg-Al LDH), and a composite of bentonite and Mg-Al-Ce LDH (B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH). The catalytic performance of the reaction systems was evaluated in terms of the degradation of IC dye and total organic carbon (TOC). The stability of the catalysts was evaluated by repeating the catalytic ozonation experiment. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals The chemicals (Mg(NO3)2·6 H2O, Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O, KOH, bentonite, and IC dye) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich in the present work. All reagents were of analytical grade. The deionized water used in the present experiment was generated from a Milli-Q ultrapure system (18.2 MΩ cm). 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The Mg-Al LDH and Mg-Al-Ce LDH were prepared by using precipitation methods. A 40 ml solution containing Mg(NO3)2 and Al(NO3)3 was obtained in a 100 ml beaker (The molar ratio of Mg:Al = 3:1). Another solution containing 1 M of KOH was prepared by dissolving KOH into deionized water. The KOH solution was slowly added into Mg and Al solution under certain stirring at room temperature. During the precipitation, keep the pH of the solution at 10. After 3 h of precipitation, the mixture was transferred to the 100 ml autoclave and maintained at 100 °C for 10 h to obtain Mg-Al LDH. The result catalysts were washed with deionized water until the filtrate pH became neutral and then dried at 80 °C under vacuum. The Mg-Al-Ce LDH was synthesized in a similar method. A 40 ml solution containing Mg(NO3)2, Al(NO3)3, and Ce(NO3)3 was prepared in a 100 ml beaker (The molar ratio of Mg: Al: Ce = 6:1:1). The remaining steps are the same as the preparation of Mg-Al LDH [22]. Bentonite was treated with 1 mol/L HCl under 100 °C with constant stirring for 6 h. The bentonite and HCl solution ratio is 1 g/10 ml. After the acidic treatment, the products were washed with deionized water until the pH of the filtrate was neutral and then dried at 80 °C under a vacuum. After that, 1 g of acidic treated bentonite was added to 10 ml of deionized water to obtain a bentonite dispersion. A 30 ml solution containing 0.003 mol of Mg(NO3)2 and 0.001 mol of Al(NO3)3 was added to the bentonite dispersion dropwise under stirring at room temperature. After 30 min of stirring, 1 M of KOH was added to the former mixture to maintain the pH at ten during the reaction. After 3 h of precipitation, the reacting dispersion was transferred to the 100 ml autoclave and kept at 100 °C for 10 h to obtain B/Mg-Al LDH. The catalysts were washed with deionized water until the filtrate pH became neutral and then dried at 80 °C under a vacuum. The B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH was synthesized similarly except for the metallic ion concentration. The metallic ion solution was changed to a 30 ml solution containing 0.003 mol of Mg(NO3)2, 0.0005 mol of Al(NO3)3, and 0.0005 mol of Ce(NO3)3. The remaining steps are the same as the synthesis of B/Mg-Al LDH [23]. 2.3 Catalytic ozonation performance The catalytic experiments on the ozonation of IC dye solution were carried out at room temperature in a lab-scale reactor. All the ozonation experiments were performed in the same system under typical experimental conditions. The IC dye solution was prepared by dissolving a certain amount of solid IC dye chemical into the deionized water. In every ozonation experiment, 300 ml of IC dye solution was added into the reactor with a concentration of 6000 mg/L and at its natural pH (around 5.6). To explicate the degradation pathway, this investigation introduced the free radical scavenger tert-butanol (t-butanol) into the catalytic ozonation treatment protocol for the IC dye solution. The reaction velocities indicated a predilection for t-butanol to interact more extensively with hydroxyl radicals than ozone. This propensity promotes the cessation of the free radical chain through the formation of inert intermediates. In the catalytic ozonation experiment, 1 g of catalyst was used. The reaction temperature and pressure were maintained at room temperature and normal pressure. To analyze the reaction kinetics and the activation energy, the temperature was changed from 30 to 60 °C. The gas flow rate generated from the ozone generator was maintained at 1 L/min, and the ozone concentration occupied 80%. The retention time of the catalytic ozonation is 60 min. The samples were taken from the sample port every 10 min. The concentration of IC dye in the solution was measured by UV–vis spectrophotometry with a Mini 1240 spectrometer (Shimadzu). The UV–vis spectra were measured every 10 min to analyze the chemical change during the ozonation. The degree of degradation of IC dye solutions depended on the TOC analysis in the TOC-V analyzer (Shimadzu). The results were found to be repeatable, with a maximum error of 5% in % TOC removal relative to the average. 2.4 Stability test The stability test of the catalysts was focused on the catalytic performance for the total ten times catalytic ozonation experiment. The catalysts were collected by filtration. The collected catalysts were washed by deionized three times and then dried at 80 °C. The repeat catalytic ozonation experiments kept the same condition as the first experiment. 2.5 Characterizations The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the catalysts were conducted on a Philips PW 1830 powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 20 mA. The 2θ angle ranges from 3 to 90° and the scan rate used is 0.025°/min. The XRD patterns determined the phase purity and crystallinity. The morphologic image of the catalysts was obtained using Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), model JSM-6390. The localized elemental compositions were measured by the EDX function equipped in JSM-6390. The XPS spectra were conducted on a Physical Electronics 5600 multi-technique system. An aluminum excitation source with an operational power of 150 Watts was used for the measurement. The BET-specific surface area, total pore volume, and average pore size of the metallic pillared clay materials were measured by nitrogen adsorption at the liquid nitrogen temperature (−196 °C) using Surface Area Analyzer (Quantachrome, model No. AUTOSORB-1). The BET-specific surface area and porosity of the catalyst are derived from the Surface Area Analyzer automatically by the measured nitrogen adsorption isotherm data. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials characterizations The crystal structure of the Mg-Al LDH, B/Mg-Al LDH, Mg-Al-Ce LDH, and B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH materials was confirmed by PXRD analysis ( Fig. 1). The Mg-Al LDH shows a clear characteristic peak of Mg-Al LDH, which is 003, 006, and 009 at 2θ= 11.6°, 23.42° and 29.84°. Different from the traditional 009 peaks, the 009 peaks in the present work were shifted to the left-hand side because of crystal changes after the long-time hydrothermal reaction [24]. The new characterization peaks of Ce appeared at 37.52°, 47.3°, 58.2°, 64.5°, and 77.4° (labeled by *) after the formation of Mg-Al-Ce LDH (JCPDS 04–0783) [25]. From the patterns of B/Mg-Al LDH and B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH, the typical reflections of LDH and bentonite could be observed, but the intensities of the peaks became weaker. The weaker peaks might be caused by the poor crystallinity of LDH since the formation of LDH was limited by the layer structure of bentonite. Subsequently, we availed of X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) measurements to elucidate the catalyst's chemical constitution and surface oxidation state, presented in Fig. 2. As delineated in the Ce 3d spectrum of Fig. 2a, distinct peaks are discernible at binding energies of 882.45 eV, 888.64 eV, and 897.54 eV. These peaks can be ascribed to the Ce 2p5/2 energy state. Concurrently, an additional trio of peaks, evident at 901.12 eV, 907.54 eV, and 916.23 eV, can be attributed to the Ce 2p3/2 energy state. Moreover, the presence of a satellite peak at 884.76 eV corroborates the existence of Ce4+ within the adsorbent. These observations substantiate the simultaneous presence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ within the catalyst [26]. Expanding on this, Figs. 2b, 2c, and 2d imply the incorporation of Al, Si, and Mg elements within the bentonite. Lastly, as depicted in Fig. 2e, in the O 1 s region, the binding energy registered at 532.08 eV indicates a C-O bond, while the binding energy at 536.93 eV is commensurate with a Ce-O bond. Similar to the B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH, the element peaks in Mg-Al-Ce LDH are shown in Figs. 2f- 2i. The only difference is that the Si element found in bentonite is lacking in Mg-Al-Ce LDH. The data on the BET surface area and pore volume of bentonite, Mg-Al LDH, Mg-Al-Ce LDH, B/Mg-Al LDH, and B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH were summarized in Table 1. Among all materials, the highest surface area (104 m2/g) is B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH, the most active catalyst in the catalytic ozonation. As the catalyst support, bentonite possesses a surface area of 48 m2/g. The combination of bentonite and LDH increases the surface area, which can be imputable to the new layer structure formation. The SEM images of Mg-Al LDH (a), B/Mg-Al LDH (b), Mg-Al-Ce LDH (c), and B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH (d) are shown in Fig. 3. Following an extended period of hydrothermal reaction, the crystallography of Mg-Al LDH appears to comprise an array of well-ordered polyhedral. Such an observation can be attributed to the prolonged synthesis duration that facilitates a more systematic configuration of the interlayer structure within the LDH, consequently rendering a more polished surface morphology. The addition of Ce to the Mg-Al LDH makes the layer structure roughly, which increases the surface area and active sites on the surface of the catalysts. With the support of bentonite, the layer structure of bentonite was destroyed. The layer structures of LDH were inserted between the bentonite to form a more stable layer structure. The SEM-EDX images of Mg-Al-Ce LDH and B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH are shown in Figure (e) and (f). Figure (e) depicts the SEM-EDX spectral analyses performed in predetermined regions to identify and quantify the elemental composition and distribution within the synthesized catalyst. The findings reveal a homogenous dispersion of all investigated elements (Ce, Al, Mg, O) across the defined region, thereby corroborating the successful incorporation of metallic elements Ce into the Mg-Al LDH structure. Figure (f) depicts the SEM-EDX spectral analyses conducted in predetermined regions. The findings reveal a homogeneous dispersion of all examined elements (Ce, Al, Si, Mg, O) across the specified region, substantiating the successful integration of the two LDH materials with bentonite. Moreover, from the EDX data, we can determine that the mass percentage of Ce is 66.36% for Mg-Al-Ce LDH and 30.23% for B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH, respectively. 3.2 Catalytic ozonation performance The degradation of extremely high concentration IC dye solution (6000 mg/L) was carried out by ozonation with the cooperation of four catalysts, Mg-Al LDH, Mg-Al-Ce LDH, B/Mg-Al LDH, and B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH. Blank experiments with no catalyst (only the ozonation process) were carried out as a control experiment to show the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Since the ozone can react selectively with the chromophores of the dyestuffs, non-catalytic ozonation can degrade the dye and remove the color in the solution. In this work, the non-catalytic ozonation process shows a strong ability to decolorize IC dye solution. The UV–vis spectra of the IC dye solution were recorded to analyze the structure and molecule change of the IC dye ( Fig. 4). The absorption spectra of IC dye are characterized by one main band in the visible region, with the maximum absorption at 610 nm. From the result obtained in the present work, the decoloration of the IC dye solution is obvious, and the decolorization of the IC dye solution was fast. In the first 20 min of the ozonation, the solution was utterly decolorized, which is evidence that ozone can degrade the chromophores of the IC dye. As the reaction continued, the characterization peak around 300 nm was reduced. However, after 60 min, the characterization peak around 300 nm did not disappear, which indicated that the non-catalytic ozonation could not degrade the IC dye completely. In this situation, the catalytic-ozonation processes were used to degrade the IC dye completely. In the catalytic-ozonation experiment under normal pH (5.6), the TOC in the solution was recorded in Fig. 5. From the result obtained from the present work, the TOC removal is around 50% by only using ozone, which indicated that the degradation of IC dye was not completed. The IC dye was degraded to other small molecules and cannot be further degraded. The intermediate will be discussed in the next section. Compared to non-catalytic ozonation, catalytic ozonation with Mg-Al LDH and B/Mg-Al LDH promoted increased TOC removal from 47% to 70% and 67%. In the first 10 min, the reaction rate was almost the same for catalytic ozonation and non-catalytic ozone. After that, the reaction rate of catalytic ozonation significantly increased and finally increased by 20% in TOC removal. There is no apparent catalytic effect during the ozonation for these two catalysts in the first 10 min. It was because the activated sites of these two catalysts were not on the surface of the catalysts, and time was needed for the ozone and IC dye molecules to be absorbed inside them. When the absorption reaches equilibrium, the catalytic performance will be the best. Unlike the Mg-Al LDH and B/Mg-Al LDH, the Mg-Al-Ce LDH and B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH have an outstanding catalytic performance from the beginning. It was due to the cerium-modified surface of catalysts. The activated sites of these two catalysts were on the surface of the catalysts, and the catalytic ozonation can occur on the surface of the catalysts. With the help of cerium, the TOC removal can reach 100% after 60 min of ozonation. To investigate the catalytic ozonation performance under an acidic or basic environment, the pH of the IC dye solution in the present work was adjusted to 3 (acidic environment) and 11 (basic environment). The results were recorded in Fig. 6 and Fig. 7. As shown in Fig. 6, ozonation performance in a basic environment is better than in a normal environment. The TOC removal in non-catalytic ozonation increased to 52% from 47%. This significant improvement should be credited to the addition of OH- in the solution. The OH- is essential in forming hydroxyl radicals [27]. The basic environment also assisted the catalytic ozonation in enhancing the degradation performance, which increased the TOC removal by 3% for Mg-Al LDH and B/Mg-Al LDH and reduced the reaction time for Mg-Al-Ce LDH and B/Mg-Al-Ce LDH. However, the corrosion of catalysts was exacerbated by the basic environment. The performance of the LDH catalysts without bentonite support descended after recycling (will be discussed in detail in Section 3). Unlike the basic environment, the acidic environment provides less OH- in the solution. It stands to reason that the ozonation performance will be worse than in the normal environment. The TOC removal for the non-catalytic ozonation decreased to 38% from 47%. Similarly, the performance of catalytic ozonation becomes worse. For the LDH materials without bentonite support (Mg-Al LDH and Mg-Al-Ce LDH), the performance degraded obviously, from 70% and 100% of TOC removal decreased to 50% and 88% of TOC removal. The catalysts with bentonite support were better able to resist corrosion but still affected by the acidic environment. In our experimental setup, we observed this axiom by conducting a comprehensive fitting analysis at four distinct temperature points—30 °C, 40 °C, 50 °C, and 60 °C. Figs. 8–10 show the results. The adjusted R2 values obtained were notably above 0.9. This unequivocally substantiates our hypothesis that the ozone degradation reactions conducted in our laboratory setup obey a pseudo-first-order kinetic model. A deeper foray into the experimental data revealed an intriguing pattern. The rate constant for the ozone-mediated degradation of the IC dye demonstrated a positive correlation with the reaction temperature. This aligns seamlessly with the theoretical predictions of the Arrhenius equation. By leveraging the power factor model and the Arrhenius equation, we determined the activation energies for the reactions. For the ozone-only setup, the activation energy was 21.92 KJ/mol. Upon introducing the Ce-Mg-Al LDH catalyst and the B/Ce-Mg-Al LDH catalyst, the activation energies dropped to 17.02 KJ/mol and 18.03 KJ/mol, respectively. This observation underscores the pivotal role that catalysts play in lowering the activation energies of reactions. A comprehensive tabulation of these data and a detailed analysis thereof will be presented in Table 2. The dynamic was thoroughly examined and graphically represented in Figs. 11 through 13, which delineate the consequential shifts in Total Organic Carbon (TOC) removal efficiency after incorporating the radical scavenger within the parameters of the catalytic ozonation experiment. An inspection of Fig. 11 demonstrates a minimal impact on TOC removal efficiency, an observation that implicates the primary role of a direct action mechanism when ozone is the sole reactant. However, a stark contrast is observed upon examining Figs. 12 and 13. In these instances, where two distinct catalysts catalyze the system, TOC removal efficiency precipitously declined from an initial 100% to 56% and 50%, respectively. Intriguingly, this decline in efficiency exhibited a direct correlation with the increasing concentration of t-butanol. These findings prove that hydroxyl radicals, produced via ozone decomposition, are effectively scavenged by t-butanol. This substantiates the assertion that the TOC removal in IC dye solution is predominantly executed through a hydroxyl radical mechanism, thereby contributing valuable insights to the broader understanding of catalytic ozonation processes. 3.3 Mechanism study As affirmed by Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS) analysis, the degradation process of indigo carmine commences with the elimination of its sulfate groups, thereby converting it into indigo. This conversion is succeeded by the disruption of the carbon-carbon double bonds present in the indigo molecule, resulting in the generation of Isatin. Under the persistent oxidation by hydroxyl radicals, Isatin undergoes further decomposition into oxalic acid and benzene. A study of the solution post 30 min of reaction discloses the concurrent presence of Isatin, oxalic acid, and benzene, signifying a simultaneous rather than stepwise breakdown of these intermediate products. In the final stages, the influence of ozone promotes the degradation of oxalic acid and benzene into carbon dioxide, water, and ammonium ions. This degradation sequence is clearly outlined in the accompanying Fig. 14. These findings substantiate the conclusions drawn in previous related academic works [28]. The XPS data elucidate that Ce within the LDH matrix is present in a mixed oxidation state, comprising both Ce(III) and Ce(IV) species. During the catalytic oxidation process, ozone preferentially interacts with the surface-bound Ce(III), which leads to the formation of perhydroxyl (HO2•) and trioxidane (HO3•) intermediates. These species subsequently partake in aqueous phase reactions to yield hydroxyl radicals (•OH), which are instrumental in the mineralization of IC dye present in the solution. As the process unfolds, Ce(IV) is reduced to Ce(III), thereby completing the catalytic cycle [29–31]. Ce is thus integral to the reaction mechanism, serving as a facilitator for the ozone transformation into hydroxyl radicals, a critical step for effective pollutant degradation. In light of the experimental findings and corroborated by pertinent literature, two principal conclusions can be drawn: firstly, cerium within the catalyst matrix enhances the in-situ generation of hydroxyl radicals, augmenting the oxidative degradation of IC in the aqueous solution; secondly, the interaction between the catalyst and ozone prolongs the ozone’s aqueous phase lifetime, ensuring extensive contact with the substrate, thereby optimizing the reaction efficacy. 3.4 Comparative study The results of the comparative study concerning the degradation efficacy of Indigo Carmine (IC) are delineated in Table 3. This table encapsulates the outcomes of IC degradation via ozonation facilitated by a spectrum of catalysts, alongside a series of disparate Advanced Oxidation Processes (AOPs), thereby providing a critical analysis of the degradation efficiencies across multiple treatment modalities. Upon comparative assessment of various catalytic agents, it becomes evident that the catalyst utilized within the scope of the present study exhibits a sustained degradation efficacy when applied to the catalytic breakdown of Indigo Carmine (IC) dyes at elevated concentrations. 3.5 Stability test Recycling tests were carried out to investigate the stability of four catalysts for the catalytic ozonation of high-concentration IC dye under different environments. A total of ten cycles of experiments were carried out under normal (pH=5.6), acidic (pH=3), and basic (pH=11) environments. The results showed that the catalysts with bentonite support could maintain over 95% efficiency after ten catalytic ozonation cycles ( Fig. 15). The LDH catalysts without bentonite support had lower stability, which could only preserve around 85% efficiency after ten catalytic ozonation cycles. The stability of catalysts under acidic and basic environments is shown in Fig. 16 (basic environment) and 17 (acid environment). The corrosion of the LDH materials is severe under an acidic or basic environment. In an acidic environment, the conversion is even lower than 65%. After the ozonation, the mass of catalysts was lost significantly, and metal ions (Ce, Mg, or Al) leachate was found. With bentonite's support, the catalysts' conversion can maintain over 95% under both acidic and basic environments. After the catalytic ozonation, the metal ion concentration of the reacted solution was measured, and no metal leachate was detected after the ozonation. This could prove that no corrosion occurred during the catalytic ozonation. The 5% conversion lost in the ten cycles of ozonation could be caused by the internal structure change of catalysts, which will block some of the channels inside the catalysts. . Post the execution of ten reaction cycles, the catalyst was segregated for further scrutiny. From the SEM imagery ( Fig. 18), it was inferred that the catalyst, devoid of the bentonite support, underwent substantial structural modifications and exhibited signs of corrosion. Conversely, the catalysts supported by bentonite showcased commendable structural preservation. Concurrently, the XRD spectra indicated the absence of certain characteristic peaks in the catalyst lacking bentonite safeguard. These observations collectively suggest that the incorporation of bentonite significantly contributes to the enhancement of the catalyst's corrosion resistance and stability.. 4 Conclusion This pioneering research offers innovative data on the efficient catalytic ozonation and degradation of high-concentration IC dye solutions. Despite IC dye's robust redox potential and chromophore selectivity, we achieved significant decoloration. However, initial TOC removal was limited to 50%. We synthesized two types of LDHs, Mg-Al LDH and Mg-Al-Ce LDH, to boost ozonation and degrade additional organic compounds. We used bentonite as a support to combat corrosion, yielding LDH-modified bentonite through hydrothermal reaction. This composite demonstrated superior stability and maintained high degradation efficiency in repeated tests. This study presents a novel synthesis method for stable catalysts under extreme conditions, providing a steppingstone for high-concentration dye wastewater treatment. Future work should probe dyestuff degradation mechanisms and enhancement strategies. Our work propels forward sustainable wastewater management. coredata.dc:description: This research tackles the pressing issue of high-concentration indigo carmine (IC) dye degradation, where concentrations reach as high as 6000 mg/L. We synthesized a novel catalyst comprising a bentonite-supported cerium-modified magnesium-aluminum layer double hydroxide (Mg-Al-Ce LDH) composite. Our investigation focused on the catalytic prowess of two versions of this catalyst in decolorizing and degrading the IC dye. Remarkably, these catalysts swiftly decolorized the dye solution within 20 min and achieved an impressive 95% Total Organic Carbon (TOC) removal in 60 min, significantly outperforming the 50% TOC reduction by ozonation without a catalyst. Bentonite's role as a support material was crucial, bolstering the catalysts' stability in demanding conditions. This study heralds a breakthrough in high-concentration dye waste treatment, marking a significant stride toward eco-friendly wastewater management practices.
coredata.dc:title: Bentonite/cerium-modified LDH composite catalyst for catalytic ozonation of high-concentration indigo carmine dye solution
